Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of instrumentation to advance our understanding of environmental processes through characterization of the organic compounds in different environmental reservoirs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will purchase an off-the-shelf instrument that has an unprecedented capability to separate individual molecules found in complex matrices and more precisely access their composition (through accurate measurement of mass). The environmental matrices that will be studied in this research and the innovative sample processing methods that will be employed to reduce the natural complexity of relevant samples represents a novel application of this instrument. Examples of new knowledge that will be created include a better understanding of how contaminants are transformed in the environment, how microscopic organisms regulate bloom dynamics through communication, and how known biochemicals are transformed into molecules that can be preserved on long timescales, thus contributing to the production of oxygen and the sequestration of carbon dioxide. Such a molecular-level understanding of these processes is essential for determining the environmental factors that regulate them and how these processes may respond in the future. The data produced with this instrument will be publically available as a mass spectral library that will be of use to other fields including drug discovery, petroleum research, and metabolomics. In addition, several graduate students and post doctoral researchers will receive hands-on access to this instrument, providing valuable training that will prepare them well for careers in both academia and industry.

This project will acquire a comprehensive gas chromatograph (GCÃ—GC) coupled to a Pegasus HRT (High Resolution TOF) Mass Spectrometer (MS), which will be initially utilized to examine the diversity of organic molecules accumulating in aquatic environments and also to identify degradation products of chemical contaminants accumulating in various environment matrices. Organic geochemistry and environmental chemistry necessarily deals with complex matrices where thousands to millions of compounds derived from various sources, acted upon by abiotic and biotic processes, accumulate on short to millennial (and beyond) timescales. Chemical structures of these compounds carry critical information regarding source, mechanisms of transformation and residence time. Access to advanced analytical instrumentation continues to increase access to such information. Comprehensive gas chromatography, together with advanced mass deconvolution afforded by the high scan rates of the identified instrument (200 full mass range mass spectra per second) enables unprecedented ?separation? of complex mixtures of organic molecules. Additionally, the sub-ppm mass accuracy greatly enhances the likelihood of unknown compound identification. Together these two features make this instrument unique. Knowledge about the processes that shape the chemical composition of various environmental reservoirs will scale with the extent to which these complex samples can be chemically described. As such, there is a significant reward associated with comprehensively characterizing the chemical composition of such samples.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
A variety of research problems in the Earth and Planetary Science disciplines require unraveling the complexity that is typical of natural organic matter. Answering fundamental questions about our present and past environment, including the cycling of elements required for life, and climatic conditions, revolve around our ability to identify and in some cases quantify, individual organic molecules within mixtures containing at least thousands of closely related molecules. Some of these compounds could include: the remnants of ancient biotic chemicals that elucidate the history of life in the Universe; clues to how oil is altered once introduced into aquatic environments; toxicants among the hundreds of man-mad chemicals accumulating in various biological tissues; and chemical structures that demonstrate how climatically and/or biologically relevant elements (such as carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus) can be stored in the ocean, soils, and sediments on long timescales. Major advances in some of these research areas are directly linked to the analytical tools currently available on the market. To assist with examining some of the fundamental questions identified above, funds from this proposal were used to purchase a High-Resolution Mass Spectrometer (HR-MS) interfaced with a Gas Chromatograph (GC) that allows two dimensions of compound separation. While a variety of HR-MS instruments have been employed in related investigations, our work shows that the superior, front-end separation capability of two-dimensional GC, when coupled with the high resolution, time of flight mass spectrometer manufactured by LECO corporation (Pegasus-HRT), provides a major analytical advantage for tackling these problems. Using the previous generation of this instrument, which had only a low-resolution mass spectrometer, we were able to identify a major pathway by which carbon is preserved in aquatic environments. However, in order to analyze these samples we had to employ a chemical degradation technique to further decrease its complexity.  Now, with higher mass resolution, which can provide elemental information not accessible to low resolution instruments, we will be able to add another level of “separation” with only minimal manipulation of the sample.

 

The GC, modified with an additional oven to provide two dimensions of chromatography, coupled to a state-of-the-art Pegasus HRT, with its associated deconvolution software, makes this particular instrument ideal for our work. Most of this year was spent waiting for the final assembly of the instrument, room preparation, and ultimately, instrument installation. An initial dataset examining organic matter isolated along a river-to-ocean transect has already demonstrated the superior capability of this instrument. After only a single run, over 300 compounds could be robustly identified by the instrument’s software based on exact compound mass, fragmentation, and matches to existing compound libraries. Using the previous generation of this instrument these 300 compounds could have been manually classified into their appropriate chemical classes (based on similarity to compounds in libraries), but would have taken at least one-month of dedicated work. However, definitive identification would have required the tedious analysis of purchased or synthesized standards to match fragmentation and “position” in the two-dimensional field of the GC. The latter procedure can be particularly time-consuming if a research question requires comparing samples run on different days or extracted from very different sample matrices because the “position” of a single compound in the two dimensional field can vary over time and in some cases, vary based on sample complexity. The high mass resolution of the Pegasus HRT significantly decreases the uncertainty when comparing different types of samples analyzed on different days. This capability is particularly important as we often need to compare samples collected on temporally separated oceanographic cruises or examine biological tissues that represent very different matrices (e.g., dolphin blubber versus algal extracts). As such, we are now better prepared to tackle the research questions that are of primary importance to our lab. Looking forward, we are confident that we can either directly or through collaborations with individuals interested in using our instruments, make significant contributions to a variety of different geoscience disciplines.
